content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a cautious undergraduate student who prefers some degree of security and predictability, I would choose a strategy that ensures a relatively stable income over the long run, while also taking into account the potential strategies my anonymous opponent might employ.

In this game, choosing R yields higher payoff (45$) in one scenario, but exposes me to the risk of receiving nothing if my opponent chooses B. On the other hand, choosing B guarantees a consistent 40$ per round and also allows for earning 35$ if my opponent chooses R.

Considering that I am playing against an anonymous player who could potentially choose either option, and since this is a repeated game with 75 rounds, it's reasonable to assume that my opponent will not always pick the same strategy throughout the entire game. To maximize my earnings over the long run, choosing B seems like the safer choice since it guarantees a consistent return while still offering the opportunity to earn more when my opponent chooses R.

In this situation, I would choose {B} as my strategy for the experiment.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

Since both of us chose B in the previous round and our payoffs were 40$, I will maintain my choice of B for the second round, as it has proven to be a stable strategy that guarantees me a consistent return of 40$ per round.

{B} is my choice for this next round as well.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this round, I chose B, but my opponent chose R. This results in me earning a payoff of 35$ while my opponent receives nothing (0$). Even though choosing B offers a lower payoff compared to when my opponent chooses R, I still think it's wise to stick with this strategy as it provides me with more consistency and a relatively higher average payoff over the long run.

However, now that I know my opponent may choose R occasionally, I should modify my strategy slightly to account for this new information. To do this, I will introduce some element of randomness in my choice by changing the probability of selecting B.

I will now adjust the probability of choosing {B} from 100% to approximately 80%, and increase the probability of choosing {R} from 0% to approximately 20%. This change should help me take advantage of situations where my opponent chooses R, while still maintaining a consistent return through selecting B most of the time.

{B} with an adjusted probability of 80% is my choice for this next round.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

However, I should still keep in mind that my opponent might change their strategy throughout the game, and I should adjust mine accordingly.
